name: Deep Brain Stimulation for Essential Tremor and Parkinson’s Disease
description: This policy outlines Medicare coverage for unilateral or bilateral deep brain stimulation (DBS) for the treatment of essential tremor (ET) and Parkinson's disease (PD), specifying device, patient, provider, and facility criteria, as well as contraindications.

restrictions.condition: DBS devices must be FDA approved or used under FDA approved IDE protocols.
Patient has a diagnosis of essential tremor (ET) based on postural or kinetic tremors of hand(s) without other neurologic signs for thalamic VIM DBS.
Patient has a diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson's disease (PD) with at least 2 cardinal features (tremor, rigidity or bradykinesia) and it is of a tremor-dominant form for thalamic VIM DBS.
restrictions.rule: diagnosis_idiopathic_parkinsons_disease = TRUE AND parkinsons_disease_minimum_cardinal_features >= 2 AND parkinsons_disease_tremor_dominant_form = TRUE

restrictions.condition: Patient has marked disabling tremor of at least level 3 or 4 on the Fahn-Tolosa-Marin Clinical Tremor Rating Scale (or equivalent scale) in the extremity intended for treatment.
Tremor causes significant limitation in daily activities despite optimal medical therapy.
Patient is willing and able to cooperate during conscious operative procedure, as well as during post-surgical evaluations, adjustments of medications and stimulator settings for thalamic VIM DBS.
Patient has a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (PD) based on the presence of at least 2 cardinal PD features (tremor, rigidity or bradykinesia) for STN or GPi DBS.
Patient has advanced idiopathic PD as determined by Hoehn and Yahr stage or UPDRS part III motor subscale for STN or GPi DBS.
Patient is L-dopa responsive with clearly defined 'on' periods for STN or GPi DBS.
Patient has persistent disabling Parkinson's symptoms or drug side effects despite optimal medical therapy for STN or GPi DBS.
Patient is willing and able to cooperate during conscious operative procedure, as well as during post-surgical evaluations, adjustments of medications and stimulator settings for STN or GPi DBS.
DBS is not covered for non-idiopathic Parkinson's disease or 'Parkinson's Plus' syndromes.
DBS is not covered for cognitive impairment, dementia or depression that would be worsened by or interfere with the patient's ability to benefit from DBS.
DBS is not covered for current psychosis, alcohol abuse or other drug abuse.
DBS is not covered for structural lesions such as basal ganglionic stroke, tumor or vascular malformation as etiology of the movement disorder.
DBS is not covered for previous movement disorder surgery within the affected basal ganglion.
DBS is not covered for significant medical, surgical, neurologic or orthopedic co-morbidities contraindicating DBS surgery or stimulation.
Neurosurgeons must be properly trained in the DBS procedure.
Neurosurgeons must have experience with the surgical management of movement disorders, including DBS therapy.
Neurosurgeons must have experience performing stereotactic neurosurgical procedures.
Operative teams must have training and experience with DBS systems.
Physicians specializing in movement disorders must be involved in both patient selection and post-procedure care.
Hospital medical centers must have brain imaging equipment (MRI and/or CT) for pre-operative stereotactic localization.
Hospital medical centers must have operating rooms with all necessary equipment for stereotactic surgery.
Hospital medical centers must have support services necessary for care of patients undergoing this procedure and any potential complications.
